quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 9 Quiz 2
quiz.subtitle: 9.2: Conjugate Acid-Base Pairs
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Relationship between acids and their conjugates

questions.question: What is the definition of a 'Conjugate Base'?
options: The species that remains after an acid has donated a proton
The species formed when a base accepts a proton
A substance that can act as both an acid and a base
A base that has been neutralized by a strong acid
questions.explanation: When a Brønsted-Lowry acid loses $H^+$, the resulting particle is capable of accepting that proton back, making it a base.

questions.question: What is the conjugate acid of the water molecule ($H_2O$)?
questions.explanation: To find a conjugate acid, you must add one $H^+$ to the base. $H_2O + H^+ \rightarrow H_3O^+$.

questions.question: What is the conjugate base of the hydrogen sulfate ion ($HSO_4^-$)?
questions.explanation: To find a conjugate base, you must remove one $H^+$ from the acid. $HSO_4^- - H^+ \rightarrow SO_4^{2-}$.

questions.question: In the reaction $HF + NH_3 \rightleftharpoons F^- + NH_4^+$, identify the two conjugate acid-base pairs.
questions.explanation: $HF$ becomes $F^-$ (acid/base pair) and $NH_3$ becomes $NH_4^+$ (base/acid pair). Each pair differs by exactly one $H^+$.

questions.question: A strong acid will always have a ________ conjugate base.
questions.explanation: If an acid is 'strong,' it has a high tendency to donate its proton. Its conjugate base, therefore, has a very low tendency to attract that proton back.

questions.question: Which of the following cannot function as a conjugate acid?
questions.explanation: $Cl^-$ is the conjugate base of a strong acid ($HCl$). It does not have a proton to donate, so it cannot act as an acid in this context.

questions.question: Identify the conjugate acid of $NH_3$.
questions.explanation: Adding $H^+$ to $NH_3$ results in the ammonium ion, $NH_4^+$.

questions.question: Which species is the conjugate base in the following reaction? $H_2PO_4^- + H_2O \rightleftharpoons HPO_4^{2-} + H_3O^+$
questions.explanation: $H_2PO_4^-$ is the acid that donates a proton; $HPO_4^{2-}$ is what remains after the proton is gone.

questions.question: Two species that differ by only a single proton are known as:
questions.explanation: This is the fundamental definition of the relationship in the Brønsted-Lowry theory.

questions.question: If $K_a$ for an acid is very large, the $K_b$ for its conjugate base will be:
questions.explanation: The relationship $K_a \cdot K_b = K_w$ means they are inversely proportional. A strong acid ($high K_a$) has a very weak conjugate base ($low K_b$).

scoreMessages.90: Perfect! You can spot conjugate pairs in any reaction.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You have the hang of the 'one-proton difference' rule.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember: Add $H^+$ for the acid, remove $H^+$ for the base.
scoreMessages.0: Review the definition of conjugate pairs and try again.
